title: 106_s1468
content: The Act may be cited as the "United States Capitol Visitor Center Commemorative Coin Act of 1999". Congress acknowledges the historical significance of the Capitol building in Washington, D.C., as a symbol of democracy and the need for improved facilities to accommodate the 5,000,000 annual visitors. Recognizing the vital security provided by the United States Capitol Police, Congress has allocated $100,000,000 for the construction of a Capitol Visitor Center to enhance visitor experience and maintain high security standards. Congress aims to enhance security and visitor experience at the Capitol by allowing voluntary fundraising for the Capitol Visitor Center and authorizing the sale of coins to support its construction and maintenance. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue bimetallic $10 coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. The Secretary may mint $5 gold coins if bimetallic coins are not feasible, with specific weight, diameter, and composition. Mintage levels can be waived, and the coins are legal tender. SEC. 4. The Secretary will obtain platinum, gold, and silver from available sources for minting coins under this Act. SEC. 5. The design of coins will be determined accordingly. The design of coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the first meeting of the United States Congress in the Capitol Building. Each coin will feature the coin's value, the year "2000", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the United States Capitol Preservation Commission and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design of coins minted under this Act will symbolize the first meeting of the United States Congress in the Capitol Building. The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the United States Capitol Preservation Commission, the Commission of Fine Arts, and the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities, with only one facility of the United States Mint allowed to strike each combination of denomination and quality. These coins will be the first commemorative coins of the United States to bear the year "2000" inscription. The Secretary will consult with the Commission to establish a role for promoting, advertising, and marketing the coins, and may enter into a contract with the Commission for these purposes if deemed beneficial. The Secretary may enter into a contract with the Commission or an entity to promote and market the coins minted under this Act. SEC. 7. SALE OF COINS. The coins minted under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales will include a surcharge. The Secretary will establish surcharges for sales under this Act, not exceeding $50 for the $10 coin, $35 for the $5 coin, $10 for the $1 coin, and $3 for the half dollar coin. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales will be deposited in the Capitol Preservation Fund for aiding in the construction, maintenance, and preservation of a Capitol Visitor Center.
